case_vignette: A parent-teacher conference is called to discuss the behavior of a 9 year-old boy. According to the boy's teacher, he has become progressively more disruptive during class. When asked to help clean up or read out-loud, he replies with "You're not the boss of me." or "You can't make me." He refuses to participate in gym class, but will play the same games during recess. He gets along with and is well-liked by his peers. His mother reports that her son can "sometimes be difficult," but he is helpful around the house and is very good playing with his 7-year-old sister.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been getting into trouble at school for not listening to my teacher and not wanting to do things like cleaning up or reading out loud.
How old is the child?
I am 9 years old.
Have you experienced any trouble sleeping or irritability?
No, there's no mention of trouble sleeping or irritability.
Has there been any significant family history of developmental or behavioral disorders?
The vignette doesn't provide information about my family's history of developmental or behavioral disorders.
Is there a history of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in your family?
The vignette doesn't mention anything about a family history of ADHD or any other specific conditions.
**Final Diagnosis:** Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
